choices.text: Ovarian dermoid are commonly associated with this
The ovary can undergo infarction if surgery is delayed
Detorsion and ovarian cystectomy should be done
USG Doppler is not a useful test in diagnosing torsion

questions.text: A 32-year woman presents with acute abdominal pain & vomiting. On examination, there is abdominal tenderness.  Ultrasound shows an ovarian cyst. Laparoscopic image is shown. Which is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. USG Doppler is not a useful test in diagnosing torsion

Explanation

This is an image showing torsion of the ovary/ ovarian cyst

Let us discuss all the options: 

  • Option A: Ovarian dermoid are commonly associated with this: Ovarian dermoids are commonly associated with torsion. As they are light in weight due to sebaceous material, they easily undergo torsion 
  • Option B: The ovary can undergo infarction if surgery is delayed: If the surgery is delayed, the vascular supply to the ovary is cut off and this can cause necrosis of the ovary
  • Option C: Detorsion and ovarian cystectomy should be done: Laparoscopic detorsion and ovarian cystectomy is the preferred method of treatment. However on detorsion, if the color (vascularity) does not return, then ovariectomy may have to be done.
  • Option D: USG Doppler is not a useful test in diagnosing torsion: This is incorrect as USG + Doppler is the investigation of choice for diagnosing ovarian torsion

Educational Objective:

Adnexal Torsion

  • Torsion involves the twisting of adnexal components.
  • Most often, the ovary and fallopian tube rotate as a single entity.
  • Infrequently, an ovary may alone turn about its mesovarium, and rarely a fallopian tube twists alone about the mesosalpinx.
  • Most commonly occurs during the reproductive years
  • Common in pregnancy.  
  • Risk Factors
    • Adnexal masses with increased mobility
    • Excessively mobile mesovaria or fallopian tubes and may increase the risk in even normal adnexa.
    • Pathologically enlarged ovaries with a diameter > 6 cm (Rt ovary more common)
    • Dermoid cysts are light and tend to undergo torsion easily
  • C/F
    • Classically, the woman with adnexal torsion complains of sharp lower abdominal pain with sudden onset that worsens intermittently over several hours.
    • The pain usually is localized to the involved side, with radiation to the aflnk, groin, or thigh.
    • Low-grade fever suggests adnexal necrosis.
    • Nausea and vomiting frequently accompany the pain.
    • Adnexal mass may not be palpable.
  • Diagnosis
    • Ultrasound
      • D/D: Ectopic pregnancy, tuboovarian abscess, hemorrhagic ovarian cyst, and endometrioma.
      • The twisted pedicle may also appear as a bull’s-eye target, whirlpool, or snail shell, that is, a rounded hyperechoic structure with multiple, inner, concentric hypoechoic rings.
    • Transvaginal color Doppler sonography may show disruption of normal adnexal blood ow. disruption
  • Management
    • Laparoscopy and detorsion: Management of choice
    • If ovarian cyst: Cystectomy can be done at same or separate sitting
    • If no return to vascularity: Can consider adnexectomy/ ovariectomy
    • To minimize recurrence:  unilateral or bilateral oophoropexy

 

Ref: Page 250, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

CT scan
Diagnostic Laparoscopy
Follow up after 3 months

questions.solution:
Ans. D. Follow up after 3 months

Explanation

The table below explains the management of ovarian cysts with benign qualities as per age group

choices.text: Transmitted mobility is absent in an ovarian mass.
Transmitted mobility is present in  an ovarian mass.
The lower pole of the mass can be felt in a uterine mass.
In an ovarian mass, the lower pole cannot be felt.

questions.text: How best will you differentiate a uterine mass from an ovarian mass on clinical examination?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Transmitted mobility is absent in an ovarian mass.

Explanation

  • In an ovarian mass
    • Transmitted mobility is ABSENT
    • The lower border of the mass is felt
  • In a uterine mass (like a fibroid)
    • Transmitted mobility is present
    • The lower border of the mass can’t be felt

*Transmitted mobility means that on bimanual examination, if the mass is a uterine mass (like a fibroid), when we move the abdominal mass byt he abdominal hand, the cervix will also move, which can be felt by the finger in the vagina

Educational Objective:

 

  • In an ovarian mass
    • Transmitted mobility is ABSENT
    • The lower border of the mass is felt
  • In a uterine mass (like a fibroid)
    • Transmitted mobility is present
    • The lower border of the mass can’t be felt

Ref: Page no 811, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th edition

choices.text: Ovarian fibroma + pleural effusion + Ascites
Struma ovarii + pleural effusion + Ascites
Leiomyoma + pleural effusion + Ascites
Brenner tumor + pleural effusion + ascites

questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ovarian fibroma + pleural + Ascites

Explanation

  • Meig syndrome has been classically described for an Ovarian Fibroma with ascites and plural effusion
  • Pseudo Meig syndrome is any other benign tumor with ascites and pleural effusion

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK559322/#:~:text=Meigs%20syndrome%20is%20an%20uncommon,seen%20in%20many%20metastatic%20malignancies

choices.text: Ureter
Uterine artery
Obturator nerve
Genitofemoral nerve

questions.text: During oophorectomy, the infundibulopelvic ligament is isolated prior to clamping, transection, and ligation. This ideally averts injury to the structure shown in the second image beneath the arrow?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ureter

  • In an oophorectomy, the infundibulo-pelvic IP) ligament is clamped, cut and ligated.
  • The infundibulo-pelvic ligament lies in close proximity to the ureter
  • It is important to lift the IP ligament so that the ureter falls back and away from potential injury during an oophorectomy

Other Options:

  • Opton B: Uterine artery: The uterine artery is ligated at the isthmus and here also there is risk to injury to the ureter. Skeletenizing the uterine artery is important at this step. 
  • Option C: Genitofemoral nerve: This nerve originates from primary ventral rami of L1 and L2; it passes through the psoas muscle, emerging on top of the muscle and travels distally to inguinal ligament, where it divides into genital and femoral branches. It is unlikely to get injured during a simple hysterectomy and is more commnly injured during a retroperitoneal dissection. 
  • Option C: Obturator nerve: Travels theought he psoas muscle and into the lesser pelvis. MAy be vulnerable to surgery in deep pelvic surgeries

Educational Objective: 

The ureter is a structure prone to injury during the following steps

  • At the level of infundibulopelvic ligament
  • At the level of the uterine artery
  • At the level of the vaginal vault

Ref: Page 811, Novaks Gynecology 15th edition

choices.text: Ascites
CA125 level of 460 U/mL
Evidence of abdominal or distant metastasis
Family history of breast or ovarian cancer in a first degree relative

questions.text: Clinical criteria of a newly diagnosed pelvic mass in a 32 years woman that should prompt referral to a gynecologic oncologist include all EXCEPT which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Family history of breast or ovarian cancer in a first degree relative

Explanation

Family history of breast or ovarian cancer in a first degree relative in a patiwnt with a newly diagnosed pelvic mass is NOT an indication for referral to an oncologist

Educational Objective: 

Ref: Page no 245, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Smoking
Tamoxifen
Combination oral contraceptives (COCs)
Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine device (LNGIUS)

questions.text: All EXCEPT which of the following are risks factors for development of the ovarian lesion shown here?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Combination oral contraceptives (COCs)

Explanation

  • This is an image of a simple ovarian cyst
  • Risk Factors include
    • Progestin only contraceptives. (LNG-IUS and progestin releasing implants)
    • Tamoxifen
    • Increased BMI
    • Smoking
  • Combined OCPs are protective for simple ovarian cysts and ovarian malignancy

Educational Objective:

Combined OCPs are protective for

  • Simple ovarian cysts and ovarian malignancy
  • Colorectal cancer
  • Endometrial cancer

 

Ref: Page 245, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition

choices.text: 2,3,4,5
1,2,5
3,4
2,4,5

questions.text:
A 24-year-old patient at 12 weeks presents to the emergency department with complaints of pelvic pain. Transabdominal sonography reveals these bilateral multilocular cystic ovarian masses as shown in the image. Which of the following commonly associated conditions must be excluded in pregnancies with this finding?

A. Fetal hydrops

B. Gestational trophoblastic disease

C. Gestational Diabetes

D. Macrosomia

E. Multifetal gestation
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1,2,5

Explanation

  • This image is showing theca lutein cysts.
  • These are an uncommon type of follicular cyst, characterized by luteinization and hypertrophy of their theca interna layer.
  • Bilateral, multiple smooth-walled cysts form and range in size from 1 to 4 cm in diameter.
  • Also called Hyperreactio lutealis
  • Due to elevated LH or β-hCG levels.
  • Commonly associated conditions include
    •  Gestational trophoblastic disease
    • Multiple pregnancy
    • Placentomegaly (As is seen in fetal hydrops, syphilis etc)
    • Ovarian hyperstimulation during assisted reproductive techniques 
  • These cysts typically resolve spontaneously following removal o the stimulating hormone source.
  • These are prone to ovarian torsion

Educational Objective: 

Theca lutein cysts

  • These are an uncommon type of follicular cyst, characterized by luteinization and hypertrophy of their theca interna layer.
  • Bilateral, multiple smooth-walled cysts form and range in size from 1 to 4 cm in diameter.
  • Also called Hyperreactio lutealis
  • Due to elevated LH or β-hCG levels.
  • Commonly associated conditions include
    •  Gestational trophoblastic disease
    • Multiple pregnancy
    • Placentomegaly (As is seen in fetal hydrops, syphilis etc)
    • Ovarian hyperstimulation during assisted reproductive techniques 

Ref: Page 246, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Homunculus
Struma ovarii
Hydatid of Morgagni
Rokitansky protuberance

questions.text: The USG finding of “tip of the iceberg” sign corresponds to the site within a mature cystic teratoma where the most varied tissue types, such as hair and fatty secretions, are found. Pathologically, what is this area called?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Rokitansky protuberance

Explanation

  • Mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts) are benign tumors comprising 10 to 25 percent of all ovarian neoplasms and 60 percent of all benign ovarian neoplasms
  • These cystic tumors are typically slow growing, and most measure between 5 and 10 cm
  • They are bilateral in approximately 10 percent
  • When sectioned, most cysts appear unilocular and typically contain one area of localized growth, which protrudes into the cystic cavity. Alternatively designated as Rokitansky protuberance, dermoid plug, dermoid process, dermoid mamilla, or embryonal rudiment, this protuberance can be absent or multiple.

Other Options:

  • Option A: Homunculus: Very rarely, a dermoid may contain a fetal like structure called homunculus
  • Option B: Struma ovarii: This is used to describe an ovarian dermoid containing primarily thyroid tissue
  • Option C: Hydatid of Morgagni: Hydatids of Morgagni are benign, pedunculated, cystic structures arising from müllerian vestiges below the fallopian tube near the fimbria

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts) are benign tumors comprising 10 to 25 percent of all ovarian neoplasms and 60 percent of all benign ovarian neoplasms
  • These cystic tumors are typically slow growing, and most measure between 5 and 10 cm
  • They are bilateral in approximately 10 percent
  • When sectioned, most cysts appear unilocular and typically contain one area of localized growth, which protrudes into the cystic cavity. Alternatively designated as Rokitansky protuberance, dermoid plug, dermoid process, dermoid mamilla, or embryonal rudiment, this protuberance can be absent or multiple.

Ref: Page no 246, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition

choices.text: General surgery consultation
Laparoscopy with adnexectomy
Laparoscopy with detorsion of the ovary
Close observation with serial examinations

questions.text: A 26-year G2P1 at 16 weeks pregnancy, presents to the emergency department with complaints of worsening right pelvic pain. She states that she had the sudden onset of sharp pain after bending. She experienced intense nausea with the pain. The pain did not respond to analgesics at home and has in fact worsened. On examination, the uterus is 16 weeks, and she has guarding. An ultrasound reveals a single live pregnancy of 16 weeks with an 8cm enlarged right ovary with high impedance arterial flow of the ovary on color Doppler.  What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Laparoscopy with detorsion of the ovary

Explanation

  • This is pregnancy with ovarian torsion
  • Ovarian torsion is common in pregnancy and is managed in a similar way
  • As the patient is in the 2nd trimester, the best management option would be a laparoscopy and attempt at detorsion of the ovary.
  • Laparoscopy is safe in the 2nd trimester.

Other Options:

  • Option A: General surgery consultation: As the diagnosis of ovarian torsion is highly likely, a surgery consult is not required
  • Option B: Laparoscopy with adnexectomy: Adnexectomy means removing the adnexa (ovary and fallopian tube): This may have to be done in case on detorsion, vacularity does not return. However the management of choice is a laparoscopy and ovarian detorsion
  • Option D: Observe: As the patient is in severe pain and there is torsion, immediate surgery is essential else the ovary can undergo necrosis and due to release of inflammatory markers, the pregnancy can also be affected (increased risk of abortion)

Educational Objective: 

  • Laparoscopy is safe in the 1st and 2nd trimester of pregnancy and if indicated should be done

 

Ref: Page 250, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Ovarian malignancy
Endometriotic ovarian cyst (chocolate cyst)
Hydrosalpinx
Broad ligament fibroid

questions.text: 25-year nulliparous woman with history of an ectopic pregnancy presents with subfertility with subfertility of 2 y. She complains of recurrent vaginal discharge. A transvaginal ultrasound reveals the following. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hydrosalpinx

Explanation: 

The above scenario is that of a hydrosalpinx. Points in favor of this are:

  • H/o ectopic pregnancy 
  • H/o subfertility
  • Recurrent discharge PV 
  • USG showing a retort shaped hypoechoic collection suggestive of hydrosalpinx

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Ovarian malignancy: This will present as abdominal pain/ abdominal mass/ GI symotoms. Ultrasound will show a complex ovarian mass with solid areas and papillary projections. It may be bilateral and there may be associated ascites/ metastases. 
  • Option B: Endometriosis: This will present as dysmenorrhoea, dyschezia, dyspareunia. Though infertility is seen in endometriosis, on ultrasound a ground glass ovarian cyst will be seen (Chocolate cyst)
  • Option D: Broad ligament fibroid:  This could be asymptomatic. It could also present as abdominal mass or abnormal uterine bleeding 

Educational Objective:

  • The above image shows a dilated fluid containing retort shaped structure which is a hydrosalpinx

Ref: Page 566, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology, 15th edition

choices.text: Skene gland abscess
Urethral diverticulum
Epidermal inclusion cyst
Bartholin gland duct cyst

questions.text: The image below best represents which of the following vulvar disorders?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bartholin gland duct cyst

Explanation:

  • This is a Bartholin gland duct cyst
  • Most Bartholin gland cysts are small and asymptomatic except or minor discom ort during sexual contact.
  • With larger or infected cysts, however, patients may complain of severe vulvar pain that precludes walking, sitting, or sexual activity
  • On physical examination, cysts typically are unilateral, round or ovoid, and fluctuant or tense. I
  • If infected, they display surrounding erythema and are tender.
  • The mass is usually located in the inferior labia majora or lower vestibule.
  • Whereas most cysts and abscesses lead to labial asymmetry, smaller cysts may be detected only by palpation.
  • Small, asymptomatic Bartholin gland duct cysts require no intervention except exclusion of neoplasia in women older than 40 years.  However, a symptomatic cyst may be managed with one of several techniques. These include:
    • Incision and drainage (I&D)
    • Marsupialization
    • Bartholin gland excision

 

Ref: Page 124, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Dermatitis
Vulvodynia
Hidradenitis
Vestibulitis

questions.text: According to the October 2003 ISSVD World Congress, which of the following terms most often describes burning vulvar pain occurring in the absence of relevant visible findings or specific, clinically identifiable disorders?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vulvodynia

Explanation

  • In 2003, the ISSVD defined vulvodynia as “vulvar discomfort, most often described as burning pain, occurring in the absence of relevant visible findings or a specific, clinically identifiable, neurologic disorder”
  • The term vestibulitis was eliminated from ISSVD terminology since inflammatory changes have not been consistently documented.
  • Vulvar pain is described as spontaneous (unprovoked), triggered by physical pressure (provoked), or mixed.
  • Vulvar pain described by most patients as burning, stinging, or a raw irritation is further categorized as localized or generalized

 

Ref: Page 124, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Bartholin cyst
Gartner duct cyst
Uterine prolapse.
Sarcoma Botryoides

questions.text: A 33-year woman presents to the OPD. She complains of difficulty in inserting a tampon and says she feels something in the vagina. O/e, a vaginal swelling is seen arising from the anterolateral vaginal wall as shown. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Gartner duct cyst

Explanation

  • Most vaginal cysts are epidermoid cysts, urethral diverticula, or Gartner duct cysts.
  • Gartner duct cysts develop from mesonephric (wolffian) duct remnants.
  • They are typically asymptomatic and found within the lateral vaginal wall during routine examination.
  • C/F: Dyspareunia, vaginal pain, and difficulty inserting tampons.
  • Examination reveals a tense cyst that is palpable or seen to bulge from beneath the vaginal wall. Observation is reasonable in most cases, although marsupialization or excision may be appropriate or symptomatic Gartner duct cysts.

 

Ref: Page no 128, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Dysgerminoma
Yolk sac tumor
Mature teratoma
Immature teratoma

questions.text: Which is the most common germ cell neoplasm of the ovary?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mature teratoma

Explanation: 

  • Germ cell tumors are derived from the primordial germ cells of the ovary.
  • The mature cystic teratoma also known as Dermoid cyst accounts for 95% of all and is clinically benign.

Educational Objective: 

  • Germ cell tumors are derived from the primordial germ cells of the ovary.
  • The mature cystic teratoma also known as Dermoid cyst accounts for 95% of all and is clinically benign.
  • Also rememeber that dermoidcysts are the most common benign ovarian tumor in pregnancy

 

 

 

Ref: Berek & Novak’s Gynecology – 16th  EDITION pg- 2374-77 ( e book)
